Does this work for field names with special characters that need quoting? Or does the field already return the quoted name?

Yes. It works with field names with special characters.
I tested with following example with field name "_a" and field name "count":

select * from hive.u_ychen6.viewtest_view3;
_a | b
------+-----
1 |   1
2 |   2
select * from hive.u_ychen6.viewtest_view2;
col1 | count
------+-------
1 |     1
2 |     2
_ doesn't need quoting AFAIK. Maybe some column with . in it's name?
Sorry, I was wrong. RelDataTypeField does not return quoted names.

@martint Any way to get properly quoted identifiers (or to quote them) for such cases?
The end-goal seems to be to generate DDL like ROW(plain_column, "dotted.column.name").

@hashhar, you'd need to have rules that understand what characters are not valid in the context of an identifier and quote them. Alternatively, you can quote all generated identifiers and avoid having to think about it.
Quoted identifiers have different semantics when you consider case sensitivity.
Indeed, but presumably, something that knows how to translate queries automatically would generate identifiers that are already normalized according to the semantics of the target.

Just double checking. Is this deliberate choice to execute Hive views by INVOKER? Previously they were executed by INVOKER. It sounds like a backward incompatible change (just noting for release notes if it is deliberate choice).

@kokosing Thanks for noticing that. I just noticed it is incompatible with previous version.  It has been running in our production environment with RunAsInvoker set to true. But if it is preferred to be backward compatible, I am ok to change.

I am not that much concerned about being backward compatible, I wonder more about correctness. The question is what is the view semantic in Hive. Does Hive support running as invoker only or as owner only, does it allow to choose? We should do what view says we should do.
I found it with a case when user has only access to a view and no access to underlying table, and query fails because we check the access to the table for that user (invoker), while previously we checked access to table but for the view owner.
Do you use views in your production environment for access control purposes?
Regarding backward compatibility, I hope that previous behavior was deliberate but I am not 100% sure.
Actually, I tested this with Hive and it works there, while in Presto I now get access denied.
